questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which two statements about the IS-IS topology are true? (Choose two.)

choices.C: All four routers are operating as Level 2 routers only.
choices.A: R1 and R4 are Level 2 neighbors.
choices.B: All four routers are operating as Level 1-2 routers.
choices.E: R1 and R2 are Level 2 neighbors.
choices.D: All four routers are operating as Level 1 routers only.

discussion.content: BE is correct. A is not true as both R1 and R4 are in the same area so will form L1 adjacencies.

comments.content:
R1 and R4 will form two adjacencies to each other. L1 and L2. 

BE is the most correct answer to a bad question

Question #74 is the same.
There is the solution:
-All four routers are operating as Level 1-2 routers
-R1 and R2 are Level 2 neighbors

So It seems, that indeed B and E are correct

discussion.content:
B and E are the correct options for me. All four routers are operating as Level 1-2 routers and R1 and R2 are Level 2 neighbors (area IDs are different).
A. R1 and R4 are Level1-2 neighbors. Not only Level 2 neighbors.
C. All routers are operating as Level1-2 (not only Level 2)
D. All routers are operating as Level1-2 (not only Level 1)

Selected Answer: BE
IS-IS Adjacency table
L1 - L1 If same Area Id
L2 - L1 No Adjacency
L1 - L2 No Adjacency
L1/2 - L1/2 - L1 If Area Id match, L2 Adjacency (Area Id doesn't matter)
L2 - L2 - Adjacency, Area Id doesn't matter)

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/integrated-intermediate-system-to-intermediate-system-is-is/200293-IS-IS-Adjacency-and-Area-Types.html

Selected Answer: BE
agree with B & E

Selected Answer: BE
To follow the consensus in the comments, BE are the correct answers.
B and E are correct!!!
ABE are all true... maybe the exam question actually asks for 3 answers.

comments.content: R1 and R4 will form a L1-L2 adjacency type, so probably A is not correct.
There is no L1-L2 adjacency type, they will for two adj: one L1 and one L2

discussion.content: BE are correct
BE is correct
are these dumps still valid?
B & E are correct.
BE is correct. I agree
BE, imo
B and E

Labbed this - A, B and E are all correct
Although technically R1 and R4 are L1L2 neighbors, so more-correct answer may be BE

choices.A: IS-IS neighbor authentication is failing for Level 2 PDUs only.
choices.D: IS-IS neighbor authentication is failing for Level 1 PDUs only.
choices.C: IS-IS neighbor authentication is failing for Level 1 and Level 2 PDUs.
choices.B: IS-IS neighbor authentication is failing for Level 2 first and then for Level 1 PDUs.

discussion.content: the exhibit is wrong

comments.content: however D is the correct anwer. Since R1 is only operate as a Level2 no L1 bpdus send or received

questions.question_text: Which BGP attribute is used first when determining the best path?

discussion.content: Easiest way for beginners is: We Love Oranges As Oranges Mean Pure Refreshment

1. Veryfy that the next hop is reachable
 2. Perfer the path with highest weight
 3. Prefer the path with highest LOCAL_PREF(100 by default)
 4. Prefer the path that was originated locally or through redistribution from an IGP
 5. Prefer the path with the smaller AIGP
 6. Prefer the path with the shortest AS_PATH
 7. Prefer the path with the lowest origin type
 8. Prefer the path with the lowest MED
 9. Prefer eBGP over iBGP paths
10. Prefer the path with the lowest IGP metric to the BGP next hop
11. Determine if multiple paths require installation in routing table
12. Prefer the path that was received first (Oldest)
13. Prefer the route that comes from the BGP router with the lowest router ID
14. Prefer the path with the minimum cluster list length
15. Prefer the path that comes from the lowest neighbor address

D is right.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/border-gateway-protocol-bgp/13753-25.html

comments.content: When you are not sure about anwers avoid posting. You confuse others. Weight is the first attribute considered. AND THIS IS A CISCO CERT EXAM

Regarding my previous post, I'm saying that because with this question I'm not sure if they want to evaluate my knowledge about the BGP path selection in a Cisco router (in which case the correct answer would be "weight") or if they want to evaluate my knowledge of the BGP protocol and their official attributes according to the RFC (in which case the correct answer is local-preference)

I totally agree with Samarjit1983. This can be a CISCO CERT EXAM but if you check the BGP RFC (https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4271#section-5) it does not mention anything about weight attribute in the whole document. So, or they change the wording in the question to specify "from cisco point of view" or the answer should be local-preference

Weight values are not carried in bgp update, so it cannot be classified as BGP Path attribute ... .is weight is the most powerful feature to control outbound traffic but it should be termed as path attribute
For Cisco Routers Weight IS a BGP Path Atribute, and has the maximum priority even above local preference. Weight is propietary to Cisco, but this is a Cisco exam so it is relevant.

discussion.content:
'Weight' is NOT a BGP Path Attribute.
'LOCAL-PREFERENCE' is the correct answer, so I'd vote for 'C'
Im sure the answer is D. Fight me!

questions.question_text: You are configuring MPLS traffic-engineering tunnels in the core. Which two ways exist for the tunnel path across the core? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Tunnel links inherit IGP metrics by default unless overridden.
choices.C: A zero bandwidth tunnel is not a valid option.
choices.A: The dynamic path option is supported only with IS-IS.
choices.D: The bandwidth statement creates a ג€hardג€ reservation on the link.
choices.B: Tunnels can be configured with dynamic path or explicitly defined path.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
By default, MPLS TE tunnels use the IGP (OSPF/IS-IS) metrics to determine the best path. However, you can override these metrics if needed to optimize or enforce a different path for the tunnel.
Hi! Im sure youre not interested, just passing by! Now click the "x" button.

Selected Answer: D
authentication message-digest, so D.
haha, I have no idea of the answer ;-)

choices.A: PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf message-digest-key 1 md5 44578611 PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf authentication null
choices.C: PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf message-digest-key 1 md5 44568611 PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf authentication null
choices.B: PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf message-digest-key 1 md5 44578611 PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf authentication key-chain 44578611
choices.D: PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf message-digest-key 1 md5 44578611 PE-B(config-if)#ip ospf authentication message-digest
